title: Credera
overview: Although we pride ourselves in the quality of work at Credera, it became clear that our brand and image was outdated and unclear. We launched an internal effort between the User Experience and Marketing teams to redefine how we wanted to present and message ourselves to new and existing clients. The Credera rebrand was launched in the Summer of 2020.
more: During the rebranding process, I was involved in crafting the website’s visual interface and experience design. Page content, information hierarchy, and visual identity were key elements that influenced many of the final design elements. I also standardized web components into a design system and branding guide and found opportunities to lead and mentor junior designers during the process.

title: Gundam Kingdom
overview: Gundam Kingdom is a locally owned store in Katy, TX that sells kits and tools for the niche hobby of Gunpla building. An avid Gunpla builder myself, I was excited when I was approached to help design and build an e-commerce platform related to one of my favorite hobbies.
more: This platform was designed from the ground up to make a simple storefront accessible to online buyers. I started by defining fonts and color schemes that would be familiar to those in the hobby. I then defined the user journey from searching for products all the way to checkout. There are many Gundam kits, so products are made to be easily discoverable, along with an easy-to-navigate product hierarchy.

title: sEATz
overview: sEATz is a unique service that aims to deliver food at major sporting events right to your seat. The app provides an easy ordering experience so that users don’t miss a second of the game. After sEATz tested and validated its service model, I jumped on board to help turn the mobile app into a clean and seamless experience.
more: Designing the app started with understanding the journey the user takes from entering the stadium all the way to receiving their food and drink order. Through this project, I was able to rethink the entire ordering process, consider and design for edge cases, and create a new visual identify for the application and brand.

title: Icon GO
overview: Icon Parking manages many of the parking garages across New York City. I designed and implemented solutions to optimize conversion rates across their desktop experience. As I grew familiar with their user’s behaviors and interactions with the service, I took the chance to reimagine what a redesigned mobile experience could look like.
more: The existing mobile application was unorganized, riddled with bugs, and unclear in helping the user achieve the end goal of booking a parking spot within the city. I redesigned the experience by establishing a refreshed color palette, making the search functionality direct and easy for the user, and restructuring the booking flow to be a clear three-step process.

title: Adidas
overview: I recently took an interest in collecting Adidas shoes - particularly those by James Harden, my favorite basketball player. While watching the Rockets game and browsing the upcoming drop of the latest Marvel collaboration shoes, I thought I would take a stab at improving the structure and usability of the Adidas product page.
more: I can’t say there is anything wrong with Adidas’s website. I admire a lot of it - the neutral colors, the typeface, and consistent use of imagery. I also recognize that there is no such thing as redesigning something unless we can articulate why we need to, understand the implications, and test the outcomes. However, as I was browsing different products, I found small bits and pieces that I felt could be improved. Though I wasn’t in any position where I could implement A/B tests for Adidas, I decided to entertain the idea from a design stance. Some changes I made included layout spacing, decluttering of excess information, and surfacing more relevant product information.

title: Pinnacle Propane
overview: Pinnacle Propane needed an internal tool to help manage their inquiries across different channels. I helped to design a simple yet functional digital platform that would enable them to increase their productivity and output by eliminating paper trails and creating a one-stop-shop for their business needs.
more: Even though this was an internal tool that would never be marketed or see the light of day, I wanted to create something that was not only functional, but appealing and encouraging for employees to use on the daily. Through this process, I defined typefaces and color palettes to create a style guide, interviewed stakeholders and users, and constructed sitemaps and wireframes that ultimately informed the final product.

title: Music Player
overview: Music players are one of my most used apps and so it comes at no surprise that I am always thinking of new or revised features that would enhance the listening experience. This is my take on my ideal music player application.
more:
I’m always using the Discover Weekly feature on Spotify, so I thought this would be a great place to start exploring my design. The page is understood to be just a list of songs in a curated playlist, so I wanted to explore ways to showcase a particular artist within the week and to also surface album art for each listing.

The next feature is the artist page - bringing popular songs to the top and also allowing the user to listen to the latest release with a single tap.

Lastly, the focus of the music player is to make everything easily accessible through single-handed use. High-touch functions, such as adding a song to a library and shuffle and repeat functions, are all placed on the right. Extra features such as Lyrics and the Queue are visible but teased to indicate that there is more to see with a single swipe up.
